rules: Rule1: Either an artist submits a proposal or an artist presents a portfolio.
Rule2: Whenever a patron sponsors a show, either a curator approves an artwork or a curator attends a review.
Rule3: A patron sponsors a show or a foundation funds a show.
Rule4: Whenever a foundation funds a show, a foundation allocates a budget.
Rule5: If a sponsor contributes resources, then it follows that either a curator approves an artwork or a curator attends a review.
Rule6: Provided that a foundation allocates a budget, a sponsor contributes resources.
Rule7: Whenever a gallery postpones an event, an exhibition delays its opening.
Rule8: If an organizer confirms a schedule, then if it is not the case that an organizer reschedules an exhibition implies a gallery postpones an event, then an exhibition proceeds as planned.
Rule9: If an artist presents a portfolio, then an exhibition succeeds.
Rule10: Provided that a critic features a review, publicity increases visitors.

Rule11: Whenever a journalist publishes an article, then if it is not the case that either a curator approves an artwork or a curator attends a review implies a curator rejects an artwork, then marketing boosts attendance.
Rule12: If media covers an event, then either a critic features a review or a journalist publishes an article.
Rule13: Media covers an event or a reporter reports on an exhibition.
Rule14: Provided that a reporter reports on an exhibition, either a critic features a review or a journalist publishes an article.
Rule15: If a critic praises an artwork, then it is not the case that a critic criticizes an artwork.
Rule16: If a critic recommends an exhibition, then a critic applauds an artist.
Rule17: Provided that a curator attends a review, if an artist submits a proposal, then an exhibition succeeds.
Rule18: Under the condition that a critic applauds an artist, a critic praises an artwork.
Rule19: Either a gallery schedules an exhibition or if it is not the case that either a curator approves an artwork or a curator attends a review implies a curator rejects an artwork.
Rule20: If a gallery cancels an exhibition, then it is not the case that a gallery schedules an exhibition.
Rule21: A publicist ignores an event or it is not the case that a publicist promotes an event.

Rule22: Provided that it is not the case that it is not the case that either a curator approves an artwork or a curator attends a review implies a curator rejects an artwork, a publicist promotes an event.
Rule23: Whenever it is not the case that it is not the case that a curator attends a review implies it is not the case that a curator misses a deadline, an organizer reschedules an exhibition.

Rule24: If it is not the case that it is not the case that a curator attends a review implies it is not the case that a curator misses a deadline, then it is not the case that an exhibition delays its opening.
Rule25: Provided that it is not the case that an organizer confirms a schedule, an organizer has conflicts in a schedule.
Rule26: If it is not the case that a curator attends a review, then a curator misses a deadline.
Rule27: Under the condition that it is not the case that a curator attends a review, a critic criticizes an artwork.
Rule28: If it is not the case that a curator attends a review, then a critic recommends an exhibition.
facts: Fact1: A gallery cancels an exhibition.
Fact2: It is not the case that an exhibition proceeds as planned.
Fact3: It is not the case that an organizer has conflicts in a schedule.
Fact4: It is not the case that marketing boosts attendance.
Fact5: It is not the case that publicity increases visitors.
Fact6: It is not the case that a curator approves an artwork.
Fact7: It is not the case that a curator rejects an artwork.
Fact8: It is not the case that a publicist ignores an event.
